# Maximum life span

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

**Maximum life span** (or, for [humans](/wiki/Humans "Humans"), **maximum
reported age at death**) is a measure of the maximum amount of time one or
more members of a [population](/wiki/Population "Population") have been
observed to [survive](/wiki/Life "Life") between [birth](/wiki/Birth "Birth")
and [death](/wiki/Death "Death"). The term can also denote an estimate of the
maximum amount of time that a member of a given [species](/wiki/Species
"Species") could survive between birth and death, provided circumstances that
are optimal to that member's [longevity](/wiki/Longevity "Longevity").

Most living species have at least one upper limit on the number of times the
[cells](/wiki/Cell_\(biology\) "Cell \(biology\)") of a member can
[divide](/wiki/Mitosis "Mitosis"). This is called the [Hayflick
limit](/wiki/Hayflick_limit "Hayflick limit"), although number of cell
divisions does not strictly control lifespan.

## Contents

  * 1 Definition
  * 2 In humans
  * 3 In other animals
    * 3.1 Exceptions
  * 4 In plants
  * 5 Increasing maximum life span
  * 6 Correlation with DNA repair capacity
  * 7 Research data
  * 8 See also
  * 9 References

##
Definition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Definition")]

In animal studies, maximum span is often taken to be the [mean life
span](/wiki/Mean_life_span "Mean life span") of the most long-lived 10% of a
given [cohort](/wiki/Cohort_study "Cohort study"). By another definition,
however, maximum life span corresponds to the age at which the oldest known
member of a [species](/wiki/Species "Species") or experimental group has died.
Calculation of the maximum life span in the latter sense depends upon initial
sample size.[1]

_Maximum life span_ contrasts with _[mean life span](/wiki/Mean_life_span
"Mean life span") ([average life span](/wiki/Average_life_span "Average life
span")_, _[life expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy"))_, and
_[longevity](/wiki/Longevity "Longevity")_. Mean life span varies with
susceptibility to disease, [accident](/wiki/Accident "Accident"),
[suicide](/wiki/Suicide "Suicide") and [homicide](/wiki/Murder "Murder"),
whereas maximum life span is determined by "rate of aging".[2] Longevity
refers only to the characteristics of the especially long lived members of a
population, such as infirmities as they age or _[compression of
morbidity](/wiki/Compression_of_morbidity "Compression of morbidity")_ , and
not the specific life span of an individual.

## In humans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: In humans")]

Main articles: [Oldest people](/wiki/Oldest_people "Oldest people") and [List
of the verified oldest people](/wiki/List_of_the_verified_oldest_people "List
of the verified oldest people")

The [longest-living person](/wiki/Oldest_people "Oldest people") whose dates
of birth and death were verified to the modern norms of _[Guinness World
Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records")_ and the
[Gerontology Research Group](/wiki/Gerontology_Research_Group "Gerontology
Research Group") was [Jeanne Calment](/wiki/Jeanne_Calment "Jeanne Calment")
(1875-1997), a [French](/wiki/France "France") woman who lived to 122.
Reduction of infant mortality has accounted for most of the increased average
life span [longevity](/wiki/Longevity "Longevity"), but since the 1960s
[mortality rates](/wiki/Mortality_rate "Mortality rate") among those over 80
years have decreased by about 1.5% per year. "The progress being made in
lengthening lifespans and postponing [senescence](/wiki/Senescence
"Senescence") is entirely due to medical and public-health efforts, rising
standards of living, better education, healthier nutrition and more salubrious
lifestyles."[3] Animal studies suggest that further lengthening of human
lifespan could be achieved through "[calorie restriction
mimetic](/wiki/Caloric_restriction_mimetic "Caloric restriction mimetic")"
drugs or by directly reducing food consumption. Although calorie restriction
has not been proven to extend the maximum human life span, as of 2014, results
in ongoing primate studies have demonstrated that the assumptions derived from
rodents are valid in primates as well [Reference: Nature 1 April 2014].[4]

No fixed theoretical limit to human longevity is apparent today.[5][6] "A
fundamental question in aging research is whether humans and other species
possess an immutable life-span limit."[7] "The assumption that the maximum
human life span is fixed has been justified, [but] is invalid in a number of
animal models and ... may become invalid for humans as well."[8] Studies in
the [biodemography of human longevity](/wiki/Biodemography_of_human_longevity
"Biodemography of human longevity") indicate a _late-life mortality
deceleration law_ : that death rates level off at advanced ages to a late-life
mortality plateau. That is, there is no fixed upper limit to human longevity,
or fixed maximal human lifespan.[9] This law was first quantified in 1939,
when researchers found that the one-year probability of death at advanced age
asymptotically approaches a limit of 44% for women and 54% for men.[10]

Scientists have observed that a person's [VO2max](/wiki/VO2_max "VO2 max")
value (a measure of the volume of oxygen flow to the cardiac muscle) decreases
as a function of age. Therefore, the maximum lifespan of a person could be
determined by calculating when the person's VO2max value drops below the basal
metabolic rate necessary to sustain life, which is approximately 3
[ml](/wiki/Millilitre "Millilitre") per [kg](/wiki/Kilogram "Kilogram") per
minute.[11][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing
sources")_] On the basis of this hypothesis, athletes with a VO2max value
between 50 and 60 at age 20 would be expected "to live for 100 to 125 years,
provided they maintained their physical activity so that their rate of decline
in VO2max remained constant".[12]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Age_dynamics_of_the_body_mass.svg/220px-
Age_dynamics_of_the_body_mass.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Age_dynamics_of_the_body_mass.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Age_dynamics_of_the_body_mass.svg "Enlarge")

Average and commonly accepted maximum lifespans correspond to the extremums of
the body mass (1, 2) and mass normalized to height (3, 4) of men (1, 3) and
women (2, 4).[13]

A theoretical study suggested the maximum human lifespan to be around 125
years using a modified [stretched exponential
function](/wiki/Stretched_exponential_function "Stretched exponential
function") for human survival curves.[14] The analysis of dynamics of the body
mass in human population indicates extremums, which correspond to mean (70-75
years), the commonly accepted maximum (100–110 years) and maximum known
(140–160 years) lifespan.[13] In another study, researchers claimed that there
exists a maximum lifespan for humans, and that the human maximal lifespan has
been declining since the
1990s.[15][_[dubious](/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute") – [discuss](/wiki/Talk:Maximum_life_span#Dubious
"Talk:Maximum life span")_] This study is now disputed on the basis of simple
coding errors and biased sampling.[16] This study also supports a continuing
increase in both theoretical and observed upper human lifespan, based on
observed data from 200 national populations. However, a theoretical study also
suggested that the maximum human [life expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life
expectancy") at birth is limited by the human life characteristic value δ,
which is around 104 years.[17]

The United Nations has undertaken an important [Bayesian sensitivity analysis
of global population burden based on life expectancy projection at birth in
future
decades](https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Publications/Files/WPP2017_TechnicalPaperNo7.pdf).
The 2017 95% prediction interval of 2090 average life expectancy rises as high
as +6 (106, in Century Representation Form) by 2090, with dramatic, ongoing,
layered consequences on world population and demography should that happen.
The prediction interval is extremely wide, and the United Nations can not be
certain. Organizations like the [Methuselah
Foundation](/wiki/Methuselah_Foundation "Methuselah Foundation") are working
toward an end to senescence and practically unlimited human lifespan. If
successful, the demographic implications for human population will be greater
in effective multiplier terms than any experienced in the last five centuries
if maximum lifespan remains unlimited by law.

## In other
animals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: In other animals")]

Main article: [List of longest-living organisms](/wiki/List_of_longest-
living_organisms "List of longest-living organisms")

Small animals such as [birds](/wiki/Bird "Bird") and
[squirrels](/wiki/Squirrel "Squirrel") rarely live to their maximum life span,
usually dying of [accidents](/wiki/Accident "Accident"),
[disease](/wiki/Disease "Disease") or [predation](/wiki/Predation
"Predation").

The maximum life span of most species is documented in the Anage
repository.[18]

Maximum life span is usually longer for species that are larger or have
effective defenses against predation, such as bird flight,[19] chemical
defenses[20] or living in social groups.[21]

The differences in life span between species demonstrate the role of
[genetics](/wiki/Genetics "Genetics") in determining maximum life span ("rate
of aging"). The records (in years) are these:

  * for [common house mouse](/wiki/House_mouse "House mouse"), 4[22]
  * for [Brown rat](/wiki/Brown_rat "Brown rat"), 3.8[23]
  * for [dogs](/wiki/Dog "Dog"), [29](/wiki/Max_\(dog\) "Max \(dog\)") (See [List of oldest dogs](/wiki/List_of_oldest_dogs "List of oldest dogs"))[24]
  * for [cats](/wiki/Cat "Cat"), [38](/wiki/Creme_Puff_\(cat\) "Creme Puff \(cat\)")[25]
  * for [polar bears](/wiki/Polar_bear "Polar bear"), 42[26] ([Debby](/wiki/Debby_\(polar_bear\) "Debby \(polar bear\)"))
  * for [horses](/wiki/Horse#Age "Horse"), 62[27]
  * for [Asian elephants](/wiki/Asian_elephant "Asian elephant"), 86[28]

The longest-lived vertebrates have been variously described as

  * [Large parrots](/wiki/Companion_parrot#Household_settings "Companion parrot") (Macaws and cockatoos can live up to 80–100 years in captivity)
  * [Koi](/wiki/Koi "Koi") (A Japanese species of fish, allegedly living up to 200 years, though generally not exceeding 50 – A specimen named Hanako was reportedly 226 years old upon her death)[29][30]
  * [Tortoises](/wiki/Tortoise "Tortoise") ([Galápagos tortoise](/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_tortoise "Galápagos tortoise")) (190 years)[31]
  * [Tuataras](/wiki/Tuatara "Tuatara") (a New Zealand reptile species, 100–200+ years[32])
  * [Eels](/wiki/Eel "Eel"), the so-called [Brantevik Eel](/wiki/Brantevik_Eel "Brantevik Eel") (Swedish: Branteviksålen) is thought to have lived in a water well in southern Sweden since 1859, which makes it over 150 years old.[33] It was reported that it had died in August 2014 at an age of 155.[34]
  * [Whales](/wiki/Whale "Whale") ([Bowhead Whale](/wiki/Bowhead_Whale "Bowhead Whale")) (_Balaena mysticetus_ about 200 years) Although this idea was unproven for a time, recent research has indicated that [bowhead whales](/wiki/Bowhead_whale "Bowhead whale") recently killed still had [harpoons](/wiki/Harpoon "Harpoon") in their bodies from about 1890,[35] which, along with analysis of [amino acids](/wiki/Amino_acids "Amino acids"), has indicated a maximum life span, stated as "the 211 year-old bowhead could have been from 177 to 245 years old".[36][37][38]
  * [Greenland Sharks](/wiki/Greenland_Shark "Greenland Shark") are currently the vertebrate species with the longest known lifespan.[39] An examination of 28 specimens in one study published in 2016 determined by [radiocarbon dating](/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating "Radiocarbon dating") that the oldest of the animals that they sampled had lived for about 392 ± 120 years (a minimum of 272 years and a maximum of 512 years). The authors further concluded that the species reaches sexual maturity at about 150 years of age.[39]

Invertebrate species which continue to grow as long as they live (_e.g.,_
certain clams, some coral species) can on occasion live hundreds of years:

  * A [bivalve mollusc](/wiki/Bivalvia "Bivalvia") (_[Arctica islandica](/wiki/Arctica_islandica "Arctica islandica")_) (aka "[Ming](/wiki/Ming_\(clam\) "Ming \(clam\)")", lived 507±2 years.[40][41])

###
Exceptions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Exceptions")]

  * Some [jellyfish](/wiki/Jellyfish "Jellyfish") species, including _[Turritopsis dohrnii](/wiki/Turritopsis_dohrnii "Turritopsis dohrnii")_ , _Laodicea undulata_ ,[42] and _Aurelia_ sp.1,[43] are able to revert to the polyp stage even after reproducing (so called life cycle reversal), rather than dying as in other jellyfish. Consequently, these species are considered [biologically immortal](/wiki/Biological_immortality "Biological immortality") and have no maximum lifespan.[44]
  * There may be no natural limit to the [Hydra's](/wiki/Hydra_\(genus\) "Hydra \(genus\)") life span, but it is not yet clear how to estimate the age of a specimen.
  * [Flatworms](/wiki/Flatworms "Flatworms"), or Platyhelminthes, are known to be "almost immortal" as they have a great regeneration capacity, continuous growth and [binary fission](/wiki/Binary_fission "Binary fission") type [cellular division](/wiki/Cellular_division "Cellular division").[45]
  * [Lobsters](/wiki/Lobster_longevity "Lobster longevity") are sometimes said to be [biologically immortal](/wiki/Biological_immortality "Biological immortality") because they don't seem to slow down, weaken, or lose fertility with age. However, due to the energy needed for moulting, they cannot live indefinitely.[46]
  * [Tardigrades](/wiki/Tardigrades "Tardigrades") can live indefinitely in a state of [suspended animation](/wiki/Suspended_animation "Suspended animation"), a state which they enter when they are not hydrated. In this state, they can withstand an extremely large number of environmental pressures, including intense radioactivity and heat, and being sent into space. Despite this, they can only live in a hydrated state for a few months. [47]

## In plants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: In plants")]

Main article: [List of oldest trees](/wiki/List_of_oldest_trees "List of
oldest trees")

[Plants](/wiki/Plant "Plant") are referred to as [annuals](/wiki/Annual_plant
"Annual plant") which live only one year, [biennials](/wiki/Biennial_plant
"Biennial plant") which live two years, and [perennials](/wiki/Perennial_plant
"Perennial plant") which live longer than that. The longest-lived perennials,
woody-stemmed plants such as trees and bushes, often live for hundreds and
even thousands of years (one may question whether or not they may die of old
age). A [giant sequoia](/wiki/Giant_sequoia "Giant sequoia"), [General
Sherman](/wiki/General_Sherman_\(tree\) "General Sherman \(tree\)") is alive
and well in its third [millennium](/wiki/Millennium "Millennium"). A [Great
Basin Bristlecone Pine](/wiki/Great_Basin_Bristlecone_Pine "Great Basin
Bristlecone Pine") called [Methuselah](/wiki/Methuselah_\(tree\) "Methuselah
\(tree\)") is 4,848 years old (as of 2017) and the Bristlecone Pine called
[Prometheus](/wiki/Prometheus_\(tree\) "Prometheus \(tree\)") was a little
older still, at least 4,844 years (and possibly as old as 5,000 years), when
it was cut down in 1964. The oldest known plant (possibly oldest living thing)
is a clonal Quaking Aspen (_[Populus tremuloides](/wiki/Populus_tremuloides
"Populus tremuloides")_) tree colony in the Fishlake National Forest in Utah
called [Pando](/wiki/Pando_\(tree\) "Pando \(tree\)") at about 80,000 years.
[Lichen](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen"), a symbiotic algae and fungal proto-plant,
such as _[Rhizocarpon geographicum](/wiki/Rhizocarpon_geographicum
"Rhizocarpon geographicum")_ can live upwards of 10,000 years.

## Increasing maximum life
span[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Increasing maximum life span")]

Main article: [Life extension](/wiki/Life_extension "Life extension")

"Maximum life span" here means the mean life span of the most long-lived 10%
of a given cohort. Caloric restriction has not yet been shown to break
mammalian world records for longevity. [Rats](/wiki/Rat "Rat"),
[mice](/wiki/Mouse "Mouse"), and [hamsters](/wiki/Hamster "Hamster")
experience maximum life-span extension from a diet that contains all of the
nutrients but only 40–60% of the calories that the animals consume when they
can eat as much as they want. [Mean life span](/wiki/Mean_life_span "Mean life
span") is increased 65% and maximum life span is increased 50%, when caloric
restriction is begun just before [puberty](/wiki/Puberty "Puberty").[48] For
[fruit flies](/wiki/Drosophila_melanogaster "Drosophila melanogaster") the
life extending benefits of calorie restriction are gained immediately at any
age upon beginning calorie restriction and ended immediately at any age upon
resuming full feeding.[49]

A few [transgenic](/wiki/Genetically_modified_organisms "Genetically modified
organisms") strains of mice have been created that have maximum life spans
greater than that of wild-type or laboratory mice. The Ames and Snell mice,
which have mutations in pituitary transcription factors and hence are
deficient in Gh, LH, TSH, and secondarily IGF1, have extensions in maximal
lifespan of up to 65%. To date, both in absolute and relative terms, these
Ames and Snell mice have the maximum lifespan of any mouse not on caloric
restriction (see below on GhR). Mutations/knockout of other genes affecting
the GH/IGF1 axis, such as Lit, Ghr and Irs1 have also shown extension in
lifespan, but much more modest both in relative and absolute terms. The
longest lived laboratory mouse ever was a Ghr knockout mouse, which lived to
≈1800 days in the lab of Andrzej Bartke at [Southern Illinois
University](/wiki/Southern_Illinois_University "Southern Illinois
University"). The maximum for normal B6 mice under ideal conditions is 1200
days.

Most biomedical [gerontologists](/wiki/Gerontology "Gerontology") believe that
[biomedical](/wiki/Biomedical "Biomedical") [molecular](/wiki/Molecular
"Molecular") [engineering](/wiki/Engineering "Engineering") will eventually
extend maximum lifespan and even bring about
[rejuvenation](/wiki/Rejuvenation_\(aging\) "Rejuvenation
\(aging\)").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_][Anti-aging drugs](/wiki/Life_extension#Anti-
aging_drugs "Life extension") are a potential tool for extending life.[50]

[Aubrey de Grey](/wiki/Aubrey_de_Grey "Aubrey de Grey"), a theoretical
gerontologist, has proposed that aging can be reversed by [Strategies for
Engineered Negligible
Senescence](/wiki/Strategies_for_Engineered_Negligible_Senescence "Strategies
for Engineered Negligible Senescence"). De Grey has established [The
Methuselah Mouse Prize](/wiki/The_Methuselah_Mouse_Prize "The Methuselah Mouse
Prize") to award money to researchers who can extend the maximum life span of
mice. So far, three Mouse Prizes have been awarded: one for breaking longevity
records to Dr. Andrzej Bartke of [Southern Illinois
University](/wiki/Southern_Illinois_University "Southern Illinois University")
(using GhR knockout mice); one for late-onset rejuvenation strategies to Dr.
Stephen Spindler of the [University of
California](/wiki/University_of_California "University of California") (using
caloric restriction initiated late in life); and one to Dr. Z. Dave Sharp for
his work with the pharmaceutical [rapamycin](/wiki/Rapamycin "Rapamycin").[51]

## Correlation with DNA repair
capacity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Correlation with DNA repair capacity")]

![Unbalanced
scales.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/45px-
Unbalanced_scales.svg.png)| The
**[neutrality](/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view "Wikipedia:Neutral point
of view") of this article is [disputed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NPOV_dispute
"Wikipedia:NPOV dispute")**. Relevant discussion may be found on the [talk
page](/wiki/Talk:Maximum_life_span## "Talk:Maximum life span"). Please do not
remove this message until [conditions to do so are
met](/wiki/Template:POV#When_to_remove "Template:POV"). _(July 2014)__([Learn
how and when to remove this template
message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template
removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Main article: [DNA damage theory of aging](/wiki/DNA_damage_theory_of_aging
"DNA damage theory of aging")

Accumulated DNA damage appears to be a limiting factor in the determination of
maximum life span. The theory that DNA damage is the primary cause of aging,
and thus a principal determinant of maximum life span, has attracted increased
interest in recent years. This is based, in part, on evidence in human and
mouse that inherited deficiencies in DNA repair genes often cause accelerated
aging.[52][53][54] There is also substantial evidence that DNA damage
accumulates with age in mammalian tissues, such as those of the brain, muscle,
liver and kidney (reviewed by Bernstein et al.[55] and see [DNA damage theory
of aging](/wiki/DNA_damage_theory_of_aging "DNA damage theory of aging") and
[DNA damage (naturally occurring)](/wiki/DNA_damage_\(naturally_occurring\)
"DNA damage \(naturally occurring\)")). One expectation of the theory (that
DNA damage is the primary cause of aging) is that among species with differing
maximum life spans, the capacity to repair DNA damage should correlate with
lifespan. The first experimental test of this idea was by Hart and Setlow[56]
who measured the capacity of cells from seven different mammalian species to
carry out DNA repair. They found that nucleotide excision repair capability
increased systematically with species longevity. This correlation was striking
and stimulated a series of 11 additional experiments in different laboratories
over succeeding years on the relationship of nucleotide excision repair and
life span in mammalian species (reviewed by Bernstein and Bernstein[57]). In
general, the findings of these studies indicated a good correlation between
nucleotide excision repair capacity and life span. The association between
nucleotide excision repair capability and longevity is strengthened by the
evidence that defects in nucleotide excision repair proteins in humans and
rodents cause features of premature aging, as reviewed by Diderich.[53]

Further support for the theory that DNA damage is the primary cause of aging
comes from study of [Poly ADP ribose
polymerases](/wiki/Poly_ADP_ribose_polymerase "Poly ADP ribose polymerase")
(PARPs). PARPs are enzymes that are activated by DNA strand breaks and play a
role in DNA base excision repair. Burkle et al. reviewed evidence that PARPs,
and especially PARP-1, are involved in maintaining mammalian longevity.[58]
The life span of 13 mammalian species correlated with poly(ADP ribosyl)ation
capability measured in mononuclear cells. Furthermore, lymphoblastoid cell
lines from peripheral blood lymphocytes of humans over age 100 had a
significantly higher poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation capability than control cell lines
from younger individuals.

## Research
data[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maximum_life_span&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Research data")]

  * A comparison of the heart [mitochondria](/wiki/Mitochondria "Mitochondria") in rats (7-year maximum life span) and pigeons (35-year maximum life span) showed that pigeon mitochondria leak fewer [free-radicals](/wiki/Radical_\(chemistry\) "Radical \(chemistry\)") than rat mitochondria, despite the fact that both animals have similar [metabolic rate](/wiki/Metabolic_rate "Metabolic rate") and [cardiac](/wiki/Cardiac "Cardiac") output[59]
  * For [mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") there is a direct relationship between mitochondrial membrane fatty acid saturation and maximum life span[60]
  * Studies of the [liver](/wiki/Liver "Liver") [lipids](/wiki/Lipid "Lipid") of [mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") and a bird (pigeon) show an inverse relationship between maximum life span and number of [double bonds](/wiki/Double_bond "Double bond")[61]
  * Selected species of birds and mammals show an inverse relationship between [telomere](/wiki/Telomere "Telomere") rate of change (shortening) and maximum life span[62]
  * Maximum life span correlates negatively with [antioxidant](/wiki/Antioxidant "Antioxidant") [enzyme](/wiki/Enzyme "Enzyme") levels and [free-radicals](/wiki/Radical_\(chemistry\) "Radical \(chemistry\)") production and positively with rate of [DNA repair](/wiki/DNA_repair "DNA repair")[63]
  * Female mammals express more Mn−SOD and glutathione peroxidase antioxidant enzymes than males. This has been hypothesized as the reason they live longer[64] However, mice entirely lacking in glutathione peroxidase 1 do not show a reduction in lifespan.
  * The maximum life span of [transgenic](/wiki/Genetically_modified_organism "Genetically modified organism") mice has been extended about 20% by overexpression of human [catalase](/wiki/Catalase "Catalase") targeted to mitochondria[65]
  * A comparison of 7 non-primate mammals (mouse, hamster, rat, guinea-pig, rabbit, pig and cow) showed that the rate of mitochondrial superoxide and hydrogen peroxide production in heart and kidney were inversely correlated with maximum life span[66]
  * A study of 8 non-primate mammals showed an inverse correlation between maximum life span and oxidative damage to mtDNA ([mitochondrial DNA](/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA "Mitochondrial DNA")) in heart & brain[67]
  * A study of several species of mammals and a bird (pigeon) indicated a linear relationship between oxidative damage to protein and maximum life span[68]
  * There is a direct correlation between DNA repair and maximum life span for [mammalian](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") species[69]
  * [Drosophila](/wiki/Drosophila "Drosophila") (fruit-flies) bred for 15 generations by only using eggs that were laid toward the end of reproductive life achieved maximum life spans 30% greater than that of controls[70]
  * Overexpression of the enzyme which synthesizes [glutathione](/wiki/Glutathione "Glutathione") in long-lived [transgenic](/wiki/Genetically_modified_organism "Genetically modified organism") _Drosophila_ (fruit-flies) extended maximum lifespan by nearly 50%[71]
  * A mutation in the **age−1** gene of the [nematode](/wiki/Nematode "Nematode") worm _[Caenorhabditis elegans](/wiki/Caenorhabditis_elegans "Caenorhabditis elegans")_ increased [mean life span](/wiki/Mean_life_span "Mean life span") 65% and maximum life span 110%.[72] However, the degree of lifespan extension in relative terms by both the age-1 and daf-2 mutations is strongly dependent on ambient temperature, with ≈10% extension at 16 °C and 65% extension at 27 °C.
  * Fat-specific Insulin Receptor [KnockOut](/wiki/Knockout_mouse "Knockout mouse") (FIRKO) mice have reduced fat mass, normal calorie intake and an increased maximum life span of 18%.[73]
  * The capacity of mammalian species to detoxify the [carcinogenic](/wiki/Carcinogenic "Carcinogenic") chemical [benzo(a)pyrene](/wiki/Benzopyrene "Benzopyrene") to a water-soluble form also correlates well with maximum life span.[74]
  * Short-term induction of [oxidative stress](/wiki/Oxidative_stress "Oxidative stress") due to [calorie restriction](/wiki/Calorie_restriction "Calorie restriction") increases life span in _Caenorhabditis elegans_ by promoting stress defense, specifically by inducing an enzyme called catalase. As shown by [Michael Ristow](/wiki/Michael_Ristow "Michael Ristow") and co-workers nutritive antioxidants completely abolish this extension of life span by inhibiting a process called [mitohormesis](/wiki/Mitohormesis "Mitohormesis").[75]
